div.head: To the beneuolent Reader.
div.p: THe opinions be manifold, and the instruments multitudes, gentill Reader, that the diuersity of pregnant wits haue brought forth in this age, and euery of those instruments serue for some singular conclusions; but I happely finding the contriuing of an instrument not bound to any particulars, but free, apt and generall, so that he is most fit to worke, most facill in working, and most easy to cary; out of my loue to those that long after these arts, I could doe no lesse then commit it vnto their reading, hoping as my intent was to benefite them with my labours, so likewise they will graint a fauorable vouchsafe to requite my paines, and that is all I seeke; which finding, I will answere then that this booke shall teach them to seeke dimensions, both Astronomicall and Geometricall, to platte and measure grounds, both Arithmeticall and Mechanicall, in such a compendious method, that the vnlearned neuer trained in the studies of these artes before, may with admiration accomplish those things that learned men haue passed ouer the moety of their liues to find out. And if this instrument please you not, you may turne further, and looke vpon the Topographical glasse, an instrument no lesse singular and commendable then the former, and for your practise whereon I haue set downe many Topographicall and Geodeticall conclusions, which because I aime to sute you with varieteis, behold the vse of the Theodelitus, the circumferent • r, with a reformation of the plaine Table, comprehended all vnder the title of the Topographicall glasse.

And since euery one that writeth a booke of any materiall consequence, disputeth first, and shewes what necessary commodity may accrew to the reader, lest other wise it be held impertinent and nothing commodious for the common wealth, (the aduancement whereof, all men are bound in Christianity to tender;) it shall therefore nothing distaste, briefly to remember the same. First then enqure of the Souldier, a chiefe defendant of his country, if he be not taught hereby to dispose of plats, castles, forts, citties, and such like, to appoint places conuenient for the campe, & to proportion euery part according to the number of men and horse: let the Politician speake of proportions, and allowances, let Architectors speake of plattes and symmetries, let the the pioners speake of conducting mines and vaults vnder the earth, for the blowing vp of citties, forts and castles; let the Nauagators speake of true directions in the vnknowen path of the seas, yea let all men speake of what vocation soeuer, and they shall find diuersity of matter, as well to exercise the head, as recreate the wit. Amongst many, I will shut vp this argument with the Geodetor or measurer of land, whose antiquity is great, as we may perceiue by Zachary, Chap. 2, questioning with a man that was meating Ierusalem; and whose commodity is no lesse great then ancient, as may appeare by the exundation of Nilus in Aegipt: for when al the bounds and limits of euery seuerall mans particular was drowned and buried in the slime and mudde remaining after the recourse of the floud, by the true direction of this science, euery man was allotted his proper quantity of ground in the same proportion it was before. Then let none grudge if we teach them the mystery and hid secrets of so necessary and rare an art, so beneficiall for man and so requisite in a common wealth, so conuenient to be knowen of some, and expedient to be credited of al, teaching nothing but truth and certainties, approued by inuincible grounds of infallable Geometricall demonstrations; and therefore we will not stagger to inserte it, as an associate to iustice, one of the foure cardinall vertues, whose office, as Ambrose saith, 1 de Officiis: Quae nihil alienum vendicat, quae cuilibet
dat, quod suum est, quae negligit propriam vtilitatem, vt seruet communem aequitatem; Et secundum ipsum, prima iusticia in Deum, secunda in patriam, tertia in parentes, quarta in omnes. For what else doth this art of Geodetia but teach directly cuilibet dare quod suum est, to giue euery man his owne? as well the Lord as the tenant, as well the buyer as the seller, as well one man as another: it brookes no deceit in exchange, no oppression of the poore, no wrong to the Lord, but aimes in all points to giue euery man his own: & therfore the office of a iust & skilful Ge • de • or, is a perfect glasse, wherein as a true mirrour we may behold a number of other vertues although some will say, they be bad members grant (in this as all other faculties) some be, shall a particular subuert the generall? A particulari ad generale, non est tenenda ratio: for we meane none of those that in base bils like players, paisted vpon postes, impudently affirme, they will suruey any Manour, and find it more then formerly it was sur
• eyed to be, such paltry bils I saw my selfe in London some three or foure yeares since, much disgracing the arte: for either they must affirme they may lye by arte, or else can enlarge the true bounds of the Manour by art. But the first platte beeing truly taken, this assertion must needs be false • but I can no more blame them to auouch this in their bils, then they are to be condemned for the paisting of them vpon euery post: shall we now turne the M • thematicks a begging? where is Alphonsus, Aristarchu • , Archimides, or some of the noble pr • fessors? if this bold, it is time to make the painters correct their Tables, and take the Globe out of the king Ptolomies band and there place a poore
• iquis, such as forlorne foreci • ers vse to haue in Pauls Church. We call the Mathematick the liberall sciences, because they should be freely taught, or for that they be most fit to be studied by great men, that haue large purses & riot wits for indeed these kind of artes he both chargeable, and difficult. But now for soath, he that can but get an old plaine Table, and measure a meadow (how vn • rue soeuer) is a Geometritian, though by profession a homely Carpenter or rude
Mason, and he that can but find the ordinary place of a planet in an Ephemerides, is an Astronomer, though otherwise a poore tradesman, of wit scarce enough to get his owne living; thus is art troden downe with presumption, and the world possest with errours. I haue heard diuers assertions and childish assumptions of such artlesse fellowes, though my selfe being vnknowen to them; some will produce you a pretty small brazen instrument forth of their pocket, and will affirme with that to goe into the middest of any field, and presently tell how many acres be in the same before he stirr • , neither will he vse the helpe of any cheine: which is nothing but meere foolish surmises and rude presumption, as farre out of their ability to performe, as they are from the vnderstanding of the art, possessing the world with impossibilities and boasting affirmations. I confesse by Art such a thing may be performed, so the medowe be plaine, and of a small quantity, but is not to be spoken in a generality, or as a necessary or speedy conclusion.

Now some there are that will abruptly say, this surueying maketh the poore Tenants haue hard bargaines, whereby all things grow scarce and deare. I answer, no: In what part of iustice is it that the Lord should be ignorant of his owne? doth his knowledge abridge his conscience? how then is ignorance the mother of transgression? is it not seene that many men of good conscience by ouer estimating their lands, let their Tenants more then hard peniworths? the randon is no scantell • can the tradesman set his friend a reasonable price of his merchandize, when he is both ignorant of the quantity and quality of the commodity he selleth, whenas! knoweth both? the vsing of his friend relleth in the goodnesse of his conscience, so is it with the Lord and Tenant, and that the measuring of grounds should bring dearth, is as false as the former. For if the tenant will couenant with the Lord, that he shall haue all commodities at the price they were in yeares past, the Lord will likewise promise the Tenant the like rate of his lands; but if all things grow to a farre higher rate then formerly they were, shall onely land be bound to rest at the old stint? shall euery
tradesman inhaunce the prizes of their wares, and onely the reuenews of gentlemen be rated? must euery one haue free liberty to make the best of his owne, and onely Landlords apportioned? It is a peeuish obseruation and foolish lenity so to doe, & is a principall cause wherfore so many tradesmen creepe into the ancient possessions of Gentlemen; yet notwithstanding it is most requisite that the Lord vse a fauorable improuement, for so to doe is acceptable before God and man: and therefore the Geodetor ought to yeeld a conscionable & true information to the Lord. But gentill Reader to conclude, let sparing reproofe assure me of kind acceptance, and then haply I shall be induced the rather to publish the flowers of the Mathematicks, not yet finished, with another instrument called Clauis Mathematica or the key of the Mathematicks; for that it vnlocketh as it were all Mathematicall questions, laying them in a plaine method open vnto thy view; the meane time I rest ready to doe thee any fauour I may,
